Award.AwardTitle: The Development Of Integrated Faunal Databases In tDAR

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will integrate data from multiple sources to permit researchers to examine how various factors such as environmental change and human behavior impacted food resources over a period spanning almost 7,000 years. The research is important and relevant today for several reasons. Faunal data in the form of recovered animal, bird and fish remains provide a valuable tool for understanding human - environment interactions but different data sets can be extremely difficult to integrate because of the varying ways in which they are collected and the varying factors which affect recovery of bone. This project will develop techniques which are generalizable and which can be applied to both prehistoric and recent data. The long term perspective adopted here and which archaeology allows, opens the door to understanding processes which may play out slowly and are not discernable over shorter time intervals.

Researchers involved in this project will explore how people living in the forested regions of interior Eastern North American variously used fish, freshwater mussels and waterfowl between approximately 10,000-3,000 years ago during a period known to archaeologists as the Archaic Period. After 7,000 years ago, hunter-gatherers living in some interior Eastern locales intensively utilized these kinds of aquatic animals, while in other places these resources were never heavily utilized. This project's unprecedented integration of faunal data sets, generated by significant archaeological projects over the last half century, will allow analyses at multiple scales and provide insight into the causes of the increased use of aquatic animals in the diets of Archaic hunter-gatherers, as well as contribute to current theoretical debates in archaeology. It also will make significant data on past animal populations and their exploitation by humans available to scientists interested in environmental change, biodiversity and other fields as well as to other archaeologists. Through the involvement of graduate and undergraduate students, the creation of a publicly accessible teaching module for undergraduate students as well as public lectures, a magazine article, and an online exhibit about the project at the Illinois State Museum, this project will engage the broader audience, acquainting them with the nature and significance of these zooarchaeological data and what they reveal about the North American past.

Temporal and spatial variability during the Archaic traditionally has been attributed to environmental diversity and to climatic and other environmental change. Recent challenges argue that this traditional, ecological perspective is outdated, has arrested theoretical development, and has prevented archaeologists from considering the role of cultural or ethnic identities, sociopolitical interactions, and ritual practices in Archaic hunter-gatherer lifeways and in related structuring of archaeological remains. These challenges can be addressed using the datasets collected by this project. At least nineteen extant faunal databases and nearly 280,000 specimens will be preserved in tDAR (the Digital Archaeological Record; http://tdar.org ), an international repository for digital data, images, and documents that provides open access and includes integrative tools for analysis. The record of animal utilization can be studied in detail at local, sub-regional, and regional scales providing perspective on the correlation between environmental, demographic, and cultural variables across time and space. Through the creation of an Eastern Faunal Working Group (EAFWG) of zooarchaeologists who have analyzed key Archaic Period faunal datasets, we will involve knowledgeable specialists in data preservation and integration, explore the comparability of these datasets, and foster methodological and theoretical collaboration. Not only will this project overcome the limitation of current syntheses by using each researcher's original dataset, it also will transform disparate variables into shared classificatory schema without changing the original databases. Thus, this approach will model efficient data integration at multiple scales for other zooarchaeologists, archaeologists and other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Archaeologists and zooarchaeologists from eight institutions (Indiana University of Pennsylvania, Illinois State Museum, Illinois State Archaeological Survey, University of Michigan-Flint, State University of New York-Oneonta, University of Kentucky, Florida State University and Arizona State University) collaboratively explored how people living in the forested regions of interior Eastern North America variously used animals, especially aquatic animals, between approximately 10,000-3,000 years ago during the Archaic period. Project participants gathered, digitized, and preserved an unprecedented collection of 58 faunal datasets from 24 important archaeological sites in the Eastern Archaic Faunal Working Group Collection, in the Digital Archaeological Record (https://core.tdar.org/collection/28092/eastern-archaic-faunal-working-group). The Digital Archaeological Record, tDAR for short (www.tdar.org), is an international repository for digital archaeological data, images, and documents maintained by Digital Antiquity at Arizona State University that provides open access in perpetuity. The collection of databases and associated documentation for this project will become openly accessible to other archaeologists, students, and the public at the conclusion of our research.   

The software tools for database integration available in tDAR made possible the comparison of faunal data at local, sub-regional and regional levels in order to test hypotheses about the roles of environmental, and demographic and other cultural causes of variable use of aquatic animals by Archaic period hunter-gatherers. As part of this project, improvements were made to the tDAR software tools by the computer scientists at Arizona State University, and these will benefit all future users of tDAR.

Research results for this project demonstrate that there is no simple correspondence between environmental characteristics, how many people lived in an area, or cultural practices and people's reliance on aquatic resources (fish, freshwater mussels, aquatic turtles, waterfowl and semi-aquatic mammals).  Rather there were many and multiple reasons for patterns in the animal use and they varied from place to place and over time. Climate and landscapes changed over the long span of the Archaic period, and the impacts of these changes on animal resources varied across our study area. Some of these changes, such as the stabilization of river systems and development of shallow floodplain lakes in some areas increased abundance and availability of aquatic resources, especially fish. However, resource availability did not determine which resources humans selected. Cultural traditions and cultural practices also affected resource selection and varied across our study area.  For example, the Archaic period inhabitants of the Koster site in the lower Illinois River valley of Illinois collected more freshwater mussels than Archaic inhabitants of Modoc Rock Shelter in the central Mississippi River valley. Middle and Late Archaic occupants of sites in the Ohio River drainage intensively collected freshwater mussels—so much so that sites along the Green River in Kentucky and the Riverton site along the Wabash River valley have been grouped as the Shell Mound Archaic. In the Cumberland Drainage of Tennessee, Middle Archaic hunter-gatherers intensively harvested aquatic gastropods (snails) and made less use of freshwater mussels and little use of fish. In all cases, environmental and cultural factors played a role. New perspectives gained from this research will contribute to the explanation of the complex reasons for the differential use of animal resources, especially aquatic animals, in the past.

The 61 new radiocarbon assays the project team obtained for Archaic period archaeological sites provide greater understanding of when these sites were inhabited or when features, such as house platforms or storage pits within the sites, were used.  They also helped us refine the timing of changes in human use of animals within and among sites across the study area.  

Given the need to compare disparate databases created by many researchers over multiple decades, this project developed protocols for assessing potential biases caused by differences in taphonomy (the natural and cultural processes that affect the destruction and preservation of bone), recovery methods for faunal remains, and excavation strategies and contexts sampled at sites. These protocols should be useful to other zooarchaeologists engaged in integrative analyses.

This project demonstrates the power of collaboration among the Eastern Archaic Faunal Working Group participants for regional comparisons. These archaeologists and zooarchaeologists are now exploring continued collaboration addressing new research questions. 

This project also makes important data on past animal populations available to scientists interested in environmental change, biodiversity, and biogeography.  These data are particularly important to wildlife and land managers seeking to restore habitats and landscapes.

The public website about the project (“Reading Ancient Animal Remains”) served by the Illinois State Museum (www.zooarch.illinoisstatemuseum.org) engages broader audiences including the general public and students from grade 7 through undergraduate college in exploring zooarchaeological methods, why zooarchaeological data are important, and human use of animals during the Archaic period.  Finally undergraduate and graduate students, particularly those engaged in introductory study of zooarchaeology, can benefit from study exercises concerning faunal databases, their preservation, and integration made available as part of the EAFWG Collection in tDAR.
